definition: Muscle tissue attached to bones, responsible for voluntary movements and posture maintenance.
Involuntary muscle found in the walls of internal organs, controlling movements like digestion.
Muscle of the heart, characterized by involuntary contractions and rhythmic beating.
The synapse between a motor neuron and a muscle fiber, facilitating muscle contraction.
The functional unit of muscle contraction within myofibrils, consisting of actin and myosin filaments.
A protein in thin filaments within muscle cells that interacts with myosin for muscle contraction.
A motor protein in thick filaments that generates force by pulling on actin filaments during contraction.
Describes how muscle contraction occurs as actin and myosin filaments slide past one another, shortening the sarcomere.
A motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates, functioning together in muscle contraction.
A type of muscle contraction where the muscle changes length, producing movement at a joint.
A muscle contraction where the muscle does not change length and no movement is produced.
A connective tissue that attaches muscle to bone, transmitting the force of muscle contractions.
Connective tissue that surrounds muscle fascicles, aiding in muscle organization and protection.
A bundle of muscle fibers within a muscle, surrounded by perimysium.
The outer layer of connective tissue surrounding an entire muscle, providing structural support.
The continuous, passive partial contraction of muscles, helping maintain posture.
A muscle that assists the prime mover in performing an action.
A muscle that opposes or reverses a particular movement, providing balance and control.
The muscle primarily responsible for a specific movement.
Ions released by the sarcoplasmic reticulum that trigger muscle contraction by binding to troponin.
Provides the energy necessary for muscle contractions.
A molecule that stores energy in muscle cells, helping regenerate ATP during intense activity.
The amount of oxygen required to restore muscle tissue to its resting state after exertion.
A protein in muscle cells that binds to oxygen, providing a reserve for aerobic respiration.
Occurs when a muscle loses its ability to contract due to prolonged activity and metabolic changes.
By-product of muscle contraction, contributing to body temperature regulation.
The minimal level of stimulation required to cause a muscle fiber to contract.
A single, short contraction of a muscle fiber following a brief stimulation.
Increased muscle contraction strength due to rapid, repeated stimulation.
A sustained muscle contraction without relaxation, caused by rapid stimulation.
Muscle fibers that contract quickly but fatigue rapidly, suited for short bursts of power.
Muscle fibers that contract slowly but sustain activity longer, adapted for endurance.
Wave-like muscle contractions that move food through the digestive system.
Specialized connections between cardiac muscle cells, allowing coordinated contractions.
The fixed attachment point of a muscle to bone.
The attachment point of a muscle to the bone that moves.
A painful condition resulting from increased pressure in a muscle compartment, reducing blood flow.
Postmortem stiffening of muscles due to calcium influx and lack of ATP.
Increase in muscle size resulting from exercise and increased workload on muscles.
A protein in thin filaments that binds calcium ions to initiate muscle contraction.
A protein in muscle that blocks binding sites on actin filaments during rest.
A bundle of contractile filaments within a muscle fiber, composed of sarcomeres.
A network within muscle cells that stores and releases calcium ions to trigger contractions.
Channels in muscle cells that conduct impulses deep into the cell, facilitating contractions.
Involuntary, sustained muscle contractions caused by electrolyte imbalance or overstimulation.
